Well claiming that 25,4nm measurement accuracy could be achieved by anything mechanical measuring device is pure bs. I design devices which operate at diffraction limited light microscopy domain. These devices operate at close to maximum accuracy achievable by mechanical  movement (in relatively large movement ranges). When measured with interferometry at nm range everything seems really inaccurate. Even the best bearing surfaces look like gravel roads in nm domain. And this is not even taking environmental effects into account. 25,4nm accuracy in measurements require extremely stable environment.

It's worth pointing out that Whitworth's machine couldn't really measure the length of anything accurately with a precision of a millionth of an inch. Rather, it could compare two rods and determine if they had different lengths down to the millionth of an inch. For instance, I might determine that one rod is 0.000002 inches shorter than the other (provided the rods are specially prepared for such a measurement). This made it exceptionally good at one thing: replicating length standards. Length standards could be made to be very nearly the same length, and this machine could be used to record the difference in length to a millionth of an inch. So as long as precision techniques were used from start to finish, compatibility between different copies of that standard was guaranteed.

One remark about "..precision medicine... gonna' make the world a better place..."(11:55).
Medicinal techniques are just tools, they can be used for a variety of purposes, some "better", and some definitely "worse", depending on the user, economic and political interests, social conventions, etc.
History shows that most technologies tend to be used for "evil" purposes at some point or another, and that the more advanced the technology, the worse the outcome.
I'm not saying precision medicine is bad, just that any tool is not inherently good, and that whether the world becomes a better place (or not) is UP TO US, not technology.

I used to work at Thoratec, which makes implantable heart pumps called LVAD's (Left Ventricular Assist Device).  The one current when I was there (now out of production) was called the Heartmate II, which was an axial flow pump whose rotor ran on ruby/ceramic bearings.  The bearing gap on the rotor was 20 millionths of an inch.  The gap needed to be smaller than a red blood cell so that they wouldn't get caught in the gap and gum things up.

Back in high school Physics class we were measuring modulus of elasticity of a steel wire by adding weight to it and measuring its elongation with a simple mechanism.   The wire was attached to a rotating cylinder that had a small mirror attached to it.  By sighting thru a sight with crosshairs at the mirror and viewing its reflection of a linear scale some distance away, we could very precisely determine the cylinders rotation angle and thus, the wires elongation.    I did the math and figured we were measuring to something like .000001" accuracy.

The Whitworth standard profile for machine screws included a very generous radius in the thread root, which offset the natural concentration of stress at the thread root due to it being the smallest cross-sectional area of the fastener.  Sadly, we did not adopt that generously radiused style of thread root.  Had we done so, our machine screws - or nuts and bolts - would have far greater ultimate strength and fatigue life!  As a side-note, I first learned of Whitworth from working on old British cars which sometimes used Whitworth machine screws, the hex-heads of which did not match either standard wrenches and sockets or metric ones, and as a result, most everyone disliked the Whitworth fasteners.  Little did we know they were actually superior!

I managed 2 metrology labs, a chem lab, and 2 metellurgy labs for a Fortune 500 tool manufacturing facility. The tolerances on our master reference gage blocks was .000004, we called it "4 millionths". We had some very nervous gages that would resolve 4 millionths. If everything is not spotlessly clean and the temperature in the lab at 72F +/- 1F, all bets were off. You could put a sensitive gage on a small piece of steel, breathe on it, and watch the gage needle spin a complete revolution.

For the ruler step-down, it might have been better to describe the first step as "one-tenth of an inch" rather than "one hundred thousandths of an inch." Both are technically correct, but the latter, which Destin chose, tends to sound like "one one-hundred-thousandth of an inch." In other words, just an order of magnitude up from a millionth of an inch. You have to listen very carefully to distinguish the difference. A tenth of an inch would be the much more common way of referring to that measurement.

That's my only criticism of an otherwise outstanding and informative video.

Absolutely love thread systems. Been 30 years since I worked in the field. But I knew every thread system in the world as well as the variations of each. I worked for a calibration/gage company. I specialized in threads, name measuring their every requirement. We supplied Aeroquip (Eaton now) and if it flew, I made or calibrated a gage to check a part on it, both domestic and foreign. I knew threads ranging from the common UN and NPT to the mentioned British Whitworth, to M, as well as all the associated variations with tapers, root radii and multi lead threads. I dont see a comment explaining how the whitworth rifle was fired with the scope off the side. The answer is that the distance from bore to crosshair is measured, so say the scope is 1.5in to the left of bore then you sight your gun to hit 1.5in to the right so your bore and sight line are parallel to eachother. From this you would simply aim 1.5in to the left of where you wanted to hit and it stayed consistent regardless of range.

Destin. Please check out Missouri university of science and technology. It's absolutely underrated. But we have a nuclear reactor, active mine, foundry, and more. It would be awesome to see a breakdown of all the cool engineering stuff available we have. I love your videos !

Destin - in the 1970's, i worked on a project to measure the flatness of surfaces for laser gyroscope manufacture to be placed in big Boeing aircraft. NIST gave us a reference piece to check the accuracy of our machine, but where we could measure fractions of the wavelength of light with our laser interferometer, their reference piece could only be guaranteed to be close, and if their random measurements happened to be at places which were a full wavelength, or a multiple, apart, they couldn't tell if it was the same height or a wavelength or more away. Our platform was a 4'x4' granite slab that rested on four inner tubes to isolate it from the floor. However, if someone walked down the nearby hallway, we could detect their footfalls. If someone rested their finger, say, or a pencil, on the edge of the slab, we could measure the resulting deflection of the granite. It was an awesome project, using some of the latest technology (like the then brand-new Motorola 68000 chip - it was so new, there were no operating systems for it, so we wrote our own just to get started.) Once we measured the tips of the triangle that formed the laser gyro, and the pieces that fit on the ends, the pieces where so flat that they would bond together by molecular adhesion when you touched the two pieces together. It was one of the cooler things i have personally worked on in my career. Accuracy for the laser gyro was such that a plane could fly around the world navigating with it and return within 20 feet of the start of its journey. It was very cool. I believe we published the article about it in Laser Focus magazine, but this was 25 years or so before HTML, the world-wide web, and online publishing. I'd have to poke around a fair bit to find my hardcopy. But it's the kind of thing i thought you'd love to hear about.

Looking at the footage from 4:55 and roughly estimating the rotational speed of the round at 1 revolution per 2.68ms, I worked out that the round is rotating at 22,388.06RPM. What makes this significant for me is this is the first real calculation I've ever done on a calculator using Reverse Polish Notation instead of the classic algebraic type notation most calculators use. So I could be wrong in my math. I estimated how long it took for the round to make a quarter rotation and multiplied that by 4 to get the 2.68ms then multiplied that by 1000 and took the inverse of that to get the rotations per second. Then just multiplied by 60 for RPM. Somebody please correct me if I'm mistaken. I just thought it was an interesting figure. Now I'd like to work out what sort of G forces that round would experience with that rotational speed.
EDIT: Well after watching the rest of it, I guess the answer came later. So my math wasn't quite as accurate as what they got. But still only off by about 15%. Which isn't too bad for just eyeballing the rotational speed.

Since you mentioned that you didn't know how the rifle was fired, Ian from Forgotten Weapons made a video about this rifle. The rifle was designed to be shot in the "Major Henry Fulton Position", where you'd lay on your back, hold the gun close to the trigger with your right hand, wrap your left arm around your head to support the stock, and form a notch with your legs to support the rifle. The advantage of this position, as compared to laying prone, is that you can easily adjust the height of the front of the rifle, required for long-distance shots - which was one of the only things the Whitworth rifle was really good at.

There are usually 4 threaded screws in pairs of glasses, and 5 to 8 in each phone; scisors are more complex. Car keys have 1 to 3. If you are watching this video on a computer, you have at least 20 screws really min for tablets/laptops (more likely around 100 for desktops).


The only thing around me that does not include screws: phone chargers.



Things that do, most of the time: bed frames, electrical plugs, multi-plugs, all watches (an astonishing quantity: easily 8-20 even for cheap quartz models), TV remotes (usually 4 to hold the PCB).


And, at a place you may not think: water pipes are standardized ... and even ... water bottle caps !!! I will say that ... 50% of the sold bottles (water, soda, wine, beer) use a standardized thread (a huge quantity of small factories of bottles don't care). This is very handy for camping: it's easy to find bottle adapters for many many many uses (portable showers, portable karshers, portable toilets, portable dog water bowl ... ).


One I am not sure about: jam and nutella pots. In fact, I am pretty sure jam pot covers are NOT standard, but who knows ...

It's ironic to see all the people in the comments pussyfooting around getting their DNA tested as if they're the children of Hitler or Bin Laden or something when they don't realise that simply using the Internet services they're using is leaving the biggest footprint of their identity and it doesn't even require their prior knowledge (who reads terms and conditions anymore, amirite? TLDR!).

Honestly guys, I may not know much in the way of information security or its implications but I'm pretty sure we need to know the full extent of what we use on a day to day basis before we start pointing fingers and shouting murder at something new that doesn't really require you to do it but uses data that's already available and ties it up to that repository.

To summarise, chances are if you thought of how DNA could be a major identity exploit, a hundred other people up above who considered making secure systems using this data have done so too, making it a scrapped concept long before this video or 23andme ever was a thing. Systems cannot be made secure with pins that don't change regularly and are randomised (neither of which the human DNA sequence is, leaving SNPs which themselves have similarities over a lineage, making the concept even more meaningless).
The HGP (the superproject Destin didn't discuss in this video) is the very reason we've been able to completely map the human genome bit by bit. It used hundreds of thousands, possibly millions of those chips to accomplish such a feat. It was so bogglingly huge, the project started decades ago and only finished sometime after the turn of the millennium.

So no, DNA is not an identifier and never will be. Its not unique enough and exhibits predictable patterns across families, if there was such an application for it in the field, it would already exist but frankly it doesn't. The only use it has right now is pattern matching.

The owner of the Whentworth Cannon is cleaning the barrel incorrectly.  To do it right you push the brush from the breach to the muzzle (just like he’s doing) but you never pull it back.  He needs to go around to the muzzle take the brush and rod out, then do another push from breach to muzzle again and so on.  Reason being he’s just dragging all the powder/carbon residue that is stuck on the brush right back into the bore every time.  Same with cleaning your favorite rifle.  Also, cleaning it mirror clean every time isn’t the best for the bore either.  Sniper rifles shoot more accurately when the barrel is fouled, until a certain point when it gets to much.  Then give the bore a good clean, then foul it with 3 to 5 rounds, and it’s shooting tight again.  Anyway, I have an airplane in my hanger that has a ton of screws. LOL

I'm a metrologist and when I read this I thought "Oh, something I know about, I wonder how much he knows of metrology..." And his father is a metrologist.

I would say that while this theoretically allows you to measure to a millionth of an inch... It's very hard to find the contact point repeatably with a design like this that's multiple multipliers removed from the point of contact. You're going to overturn a bit or underturn a bit. Sort of like if you take a micrometer that measures down to 50 millionths of an inch... you will rarely get a repeatable measurement to that spec on anything that isn't 100% contact like a gage block. It's just too hard to know when you've hit the right level of force even with the slip click ratchet type. If you're not perfectly aligned with the face you'll feel contact but are at an angle like \ \ instead of | | and it makes the object appear larger. It's very difficult to get out of a measurement perfectly.

Additionally you need a very flat face on the measurement tool to get repeatable measurements. We measure the flatness of the steel using monochromatic lights and interference lines in an optical flat, but none of those go down to 1 millionth of an inch, the half wavelength of helium for example is only 11.6u" and I'm fairly confident that he couldn't check his equipment to the accuracy needed.

He had resolution down to a millionth of an inch, but he couldn't measure a millionth of an inch. My best set of NIST traceable gage blocks is +/- 6u" and my best traceable linear standard is +/- 20u" in my supermicrometer which has an adjustable weighted anvil to ensure more reliably tightened contact measurements.

I still have a thread micrometer for US UN (60 deg included angle) It has various size anvils for various pitch threads (UN=4 through UN-56). At around 12:53 is an illustration of Whitworth's Standard Thread Form. Notice the generous radius at the root of the thread. Had we adopted such a form, with such a relatively large radius at the root, our fasteners would enjoy a vastly improved failure rate. Threaded fasteners always, always fail at the thread root where stresses concentrate because it is the thinnest cross-sectional area. Our sharp thread roots offer a stress-raiser to initiate a crack more easily than a wide radius would. Even a flattened thread root still has sharp corners (two of them!) compared to Whitworth's radius.

I’ve always been absolutely fascinated by Whitworth rifles. Not because of their efficiency at dealing lethal damage, but because of the sheer precision. The Whitworth could put up nearly the same groups at 1400yds as an Enfield rifle-musket would at 500yds. Almost three times more accurate in an age 100 years before high-precision numerically-controlled machining tools. Moral of the story- don’t feel bad if you don’t have access to a CNC machine. Pull out your gauges and calipers, and if you work hard enough and have the patience, you can do anything you want.

I ran up against thread standards repairing a Bacon banjo. It's about 100 years old, and the machine screws holding the tuners together are 36tpi -- apparently that size didn't make it into the modern standard; it skips from 32tpi to 40tpi. At least in North America. It's possible that although the Banjo was made in America, they were getting machine screws from England.

That's a really fascinating look into metrology and manufacturing; thank you! That being said, Whitworth wasn't entirely successful in standardizing thread pitches. Note that thread pitches that bear his name (British Standard Whitworth) are not common, and those of us who have dealt with vintage machinery -- e.g. older British vehicles, and some workshop equipment at least through the 1970s -- have felt the struggle of either switching BSW fasteners to SAE or metric ones, or sourcing vintage or uncommon hardware. Most recently I needed a 1/2"x12TPI BSW bolt to restore an old bench vise. The solution was to manufacture an entirely new fastener on my lathe rather than source BSW hardware.

Like all freshman at St. John's College in Annapolis, I began the Theory of Measurement lab using a (somewhat cruder) version of Whitworth's technique of producing a true plane. We ground three blocks of soapstone against each other until one could inscribe a chalk grid on the ground surface of any of the blocks and place each of the other two ground surfaces on it, rotate it and uniformly smear the grid. Getting two surfaces to mate is not enough since one could be concave and the other convex. No student left the lab who wasn't covered in fine talc outlining where the apron was. 😖😜
Only when we had thus produced a true plane could we produce a straight edge and go on to generate a spiral to make a log scale for our slide rules.

Whitworth's surface plates were finished by hand scraping, and compared to another plate. However if you use two plates, you could scrape one convex and one concave and the two would still fit together but not be flat. So you would use a third plate and when you achieved a good match between all three, you would know that all three were flat.

A little piece of trivia:
As you fire a smootbore gun time and time again, the bore becomes more and more gunked with black powder residue. Eventually, you won't be able to ram a bullet down the bore. That was not due to poor maintaining of a weapon, as it could happen during a long battle.
Rifling was originally invented to give a place for that residue to go, allowing more time between cleanups.
Eventually, somebody figured out it was easier to broach the bore while twisting it. Then they noticed guns done this way were particularly more accurate. And they had no idea why. All they knew was that the twisted grooves made the bullet spin on it's axis, but they had no idea why that made it more accurate.
Legends even tell of one of those rifles outperforming a smoothbore firing silver bullets marked with a cross and blessed my a priest, but that's probably a myth.
Then, Illuminism happened and scholars set out to figure out exactly what made them more precise. Up until then, a soldier was expected to hit his target at 50 (45ish meters), was considered lucky to hit anything at 100yd (91m) and the soldier who was hit at or beyond 150 yd was extremely unlucky.
Rifling changed that, reportedly allowing killshots at 1000yds. The Sharpshooter was born, a man who could decide a battle with a single shot to the right target. And then generals stopped leading charges from the front.

i noticed in the early scenes of the video there was a lot of shaking, a handy tool to fix this (if you are using adobe premier pro) is to add a warp stabilizer to that video clip
step 1. Select your video clip of choice
step 2. Click the search bar in the little effects box
step 3. Then you must type 'Warp Stabilizer'
step 4. Drag the warp stabilizer onto the video clip of choice
just like that you may see a smoother piece of footage and as you get more comfortable with it you can adjust how much warping or other effects to also give a better result.
Kind Regards, David

Not only are Imperial units and SI (metric) units different, but the pitch on threaded fasteners is measured differently. In the Imperial system, thread pitch is measured in threads per inch (TPI). In the SI system, it is measured in millimeters per thread. Nugget of knowledge.

Back in the '70' as an apprentice tool and die maker I ground plastic injection mold parts for electronic components to 50 millionths of an inch. We had a temperature controlled tool room and could not touch things with bare hands. After grinding had to let parts sit 24 hours to stabilize even after using coolant. Would use gauge blocks to be at target dimension and place ground part next to gauge blocks and place an optical flat (a very precise parallel ground quartz crystal) on top of the gauge blocks and ground part and use a monochromatic light source (mercury vapor) to shine down on the optical flat and count the lines of interference seen between the bottom of optical flat and top of ground part and using calculations determine the difference in height between gauge blocks(target dimension) and ground part(actual or true dimension). Good fun.

back in the late 70's early 80's, I worked for Snap-Tite, Inc. One of their product lines was the "Fire Hose division". As this was prior to standardization of threaded hose connectors, we would have to make adaptors for each fire company that ordered our hose and other fire related products. We manufactured "stortz" connectors (a kind of quick connect coupling for fire hose) The threaded side of these connectors was always Whitworth threads. I became a little familiar with Whitworh through the process of learning about our Fire equipment product line as I was given that task as part of my responsibilities in our engineering dept. Learned a lot about quality control, doing thread calculations, machining and tooling among many other engineering tasks. Did not know about Whitworth's contribution to fire arms. Recently bought a Sonos Beam speaker, but all the mounts they had for it, were wall mounted. My TV is wall mounted, so I wanted the speaker to be TV mounted. I figured, since the stand is not screwed in, I can buy 2 pieces of L-shaped brackets, drill holes in them to match the TV mount holes and Speaker holes, and make my own TV mount for the speaker. I used the 6 M3 screws for the TV, and 2 M5 screws I bought at Home Depot for the speaker.

It took me 6 hours of shopping, drilling, filing, painting and $30 in parts. But I think it was worth it, as it looks unique and cool.
Oh yeah, had to educate myself on thread depth and gauge, as the guys at Home Depot were no help.

Whitworth certainly made modern living possible. Just standardizing parts is an amazing accomplishment. However, the tiny microchips and circuits we rely on every day wouldn't exist if not for his precise and tiny measurements.
I had a friend, years ago, he was older by a decent chunk, and he worked, among other places, in nuclear reactors, measuring changes in the physical parts of the reactors. He was a very hands-on, handy, tool-using, make-it-yourself kind of guy. He would use lasers to do most of the measurements in the reactors, and even the floors had to be level to within a very small degree of error.
He couldn't go into all kinds of details about a lot of his work, especially the work he did in the army, but he constantly impressed upon me the fact that we live in an astonishing age. He never failed to give God the glory for what he was able to do and the blessings in his life. I think he would have liked this channel (maybe he's watching it now, hey Moe!).

People mock the American inch system as being crude and irrational. It is, however, based on a binary progression. Just by having a 1 inch standard, one could easily divide it in 2, with relatively simple tools and keep dividing the result by 2 ie. 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16 etc.. That's why America became an industrial giant while much of the world, including Europe, was still living in trees. If the american inch system is irrational, so is binary. It's like the old adage; "There are 10 kinds of people in the world; those who understand binary and those who don't."

I once worked for a biomedical tubular manufacturer company where we made the material for marker bands, catheters stents ect.  We used a laser mic and a set of electronic scales. so  our method was to laser mic the outside in 4 different point's,  then a length of measurement for  the overall length and the weight of the material.
